entry.title: Ground plane segmentation(RANSAC) and clustering(DBSCAN)
entry.content:
Task

Use KITTI 3D object detection dataset
Remove the ground from the lidar points, visualize ground as blue
Clustering over the remaining points, visualize the clusters with random color

RANSAC for ground segmentation

RANSAC(RANdom SAmple Consensus) has a good performance only when the inlier ratio is good enough.

Advantages:

Works well in practice, even with low inlier ratio like 10%

Disadvantages:

Some hyperparameters like inlier threshold τ\tauτ
Need lots of samples when inlier ratio is low

It has 5 steps：

1, Select a minimal subset of samples

How many parameters to be fitted, then how many samples we choose.
In this task, 3 points are needed to fit a plane in 3D space, it needs to be satisfied that 3 points can determine a plane, they are not on the same line.

There are 2 ways to decide if these 3 points are on a line:

1.1, Full rank

while True:
    sample_index= random.sample(range(sz),3)
    p= data[sample_index,:]
    if np.linalg.matrix_rank(p)==3:
        break

1.2, Vector relations

# 3 points make 2 vectors
vector1= xyz[1,:] -xyz[0,:]
vector2= xyz[2,:] -xyz[0,:]
if not np.all(vector1):
    print("will divide by zero",vector1)
    return None
dy1dy2 = vector2 / vector1
# if the two vectors are collinear, their ratio on x, y, z will be the same
if not ( (dy1dy2[0]!=dy1dy2[1]) or (dy1dy2[2]!=dy1dy2[1]) ):
    return None

2, Solve the model

There are 2 ways to build a plane model based on the chosen 3 points: p1,p2,p3

2.1, PCA

The eigenvector corresponding to the minimin eigenvalue, is the normal direction of the plane.

2.2, Cross product

p12= p2-p1
p13= p3-p1
n=np.cross(p12,p13)
n=n / np.linalg.norm(n) # normalized norm function

2.3, Tricks to fit the ground plane better

  1. LiDAR sensor fixed at a constant hight of a vehicle, about 1.7m ~ 2m. Therefore, only points has 'z' at -2~-1.5 will be considered.
  2. Ground plane's norm close to the 'z' direction, therefore, the plane fitted by walls can be excluded.
  3. Subsection model. Divide the ground into zones and extract inliers for each zone, therefore the distant points can be detected correctly.

3, Compute error function

In Eucledian space, calculate the distance to plane for every point.

count = 0
for point in data:
    d = abs(np.dot((point-p1),n)) # n is the norm of the ground plane

4, Count the points consistent with the model

The hyperparameter τ\tauτ is the distance threshold for inlier.
Label the point as inlier when the distance less than the threshold. Otherwise, label the point as outlier when the distance larger than the threshold.

5, Choose the model with most inlier points

Repeat steps 1~4 for N iterations and choose the optimum model.

5,1 How to set the iteration times N?

We can assign a iteration times by experience, or calculate the optimum iteration times based on statistics.
e: outlier ratio
s: number of points in a sample
p: confidence we get at least a good sample that is not outlier
The following fomula means repeat N times, so that with propability "p", at least one random sample is free from outliers.
N=log(1−p)log(1−(1−e)s)N=\dfrac{log(1-p)}{log(1-(1-e)^s)}N=log(1−(1−e)s)log(1−p)​

# suppose propability p=0.99，outlier_ratio=0.5,  s=3 for 3D plane model.
iteration_num= math.ceil(math.log(1-0.99)/math.log(1-power(0.5,3)))

5.2 How to stop iteration in advance?

When enough inlier points in this model.
inlierpointsnumbertotalpointsnumber⩾1−e\dfrac{inlier points number}{total points number} \geqslant {1-e}totalpointsnumberinlierpointsnumber​⩾1−e

5.3 How to refine the model?

Run LSQ(Least SQuare) to refine the model after the model and inlier points are selected.

Clustering on DBSCAN

After removing the points on ground plane, the points are sparse, in this situation, DBSCAN can be used to make clustering.

Advantages:

It not require to specify the number of clusters.

Algorithm flow

DBSCAN(Density-based spatial clustering of applications with noise) is a data clustering algorithm, it groups points with many nearby neighbors, and marking points in low density regions as outliers. In DBSCAN, points are classified as core points, reachable points and outliers.

findNeigborsInDist(point, distTh)
{
    neighbors=point.KDTree(distTh)
    return neighbors, sizeof(neighbors)
}    
for point in unvisitedPoints:
    neiPoints, nums = findNeigborsInDist(point, distThreshold)
    if nums < numsThreshold:
        label all the points in neiPoints as outliers
    else
        label all the points in neiPoints as corepoints

entry.title: LiDAR feature detection
entry.content:
feature detection: Identity the interest points.

Why not ICP

ICP(Iterative Closest Point) requires proper initial guess.
ICP requires a high overlapping ratio. With the increase of overlapping ratios, the convergence accuracy and speed of ICP algorithm improves.

Traditional method to detect and match features

Ideas from image -- Harris

Consider a patch in an Image, w(x,y) is the windows function, means the weight of points in the patch are >0( or 1 for simplify), for points outside the patch are 0.
In image, to get the gradient of the (x,y), we can make a small shift of the patch by [u,v], the intensity change is
E(u,v)=Σw(x,y)[I(x+u,y+v)−I(x,y)]2≈I(x,y)+uIx(x,y)+vIy(x,y)−I(x,y)≈uIx(x,y)+vIy(x,y)E(u,v)=\Sigma w(x,y)[I(x+u,y+v)-I(x,y)]^{2} \approx {I(x,y)+uI_{x}(x,y)+vI_{y}(x,y)-I(x,y)} \approx {uI_{x}(x,y)+vI_{y}(x,y)}E(u,v)=Σw(x,y)[I(x+u,y+v)−I(x,y)]2≈I(x,y)+uIx​(x,y)+vIy​(x,y)−I(x,y)≈uIx​(x,y)+vIy​(x,y)

In 3D space,
E(u,v,w)=[uvw][Ix2IxIyIxIzIxIyIy2IyIzIxIzIyIzIz2][uvw]E(u,v,w)=[u v w] \left[\begin{matrix} {I_{x}}^{2} & I_{x}I_{y} & I_{x}I_{z}\\ I_{x}I_{y} & {I_{y}}^{2} & I_{y}I_{z}\\ I_{x}I_{z} & I_{y}I_{z} & {I_{z}}^{2} \end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix} u \\ v \\ w \end{matrix}\right]E(u,v,w)=[uvw]⎣⎡​Ix​2Ix​Iy​Ix​Iz​​Ix​Iy​Iy​2Iy​Iz​​Ix​Iz​Iy​Iz​Iz​2​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​uvw​⎦⎤​
Take matrix M to describe the covariance matrix of the point gradient
M=[Ix2IxIyIxIzIxIyIy2IyIzIxIzIyIzIz2]M=\left[\begin{matrix} {I_{x}}^{2} & I_{x}I_{y} & I_{x}I_{z}\\ I_{x}I_{y} & {I_{y}}^{2} & I_{y}I_{z}\\ I_{x}I_{z} & I_{y}I_{z} & {I_{z}}^{2} \end{matrix}\right]M=⎣⎡​Ix​2Ix​Iy​Ix​Iz​​Ix​Iy​Iy​2Iy​Iz​​Ix​Iz​Iy​Iz​Iz​2​⎦⎤​
It's easy to get the first order gradient e=[Ix，Iy，Iz]\bm{e}=[I_{x}，I_{y}，I_{z}]e=[Ix​，Iy​，Iz​], then project e\bm{e}e onto local surface, thus may reduce the effect of noise.
How to project e\bm{e}e onto surface/curve? e′=e−n(nTe)=e−n(eTn)\bm{e'}=\bm{e}-\bm{n(n^{T}e)}=\bm{e}-\bm{n(e^{T}n)}e′=e−n(nTe)=e−n(eTn)
How to compute corner response? assume eigenvalues are sorted from large to small.
R=λ3R=\lambda_3R=λ3​ is a corner point in 3D space, besides that, R=λ2R=\lambda_2R=λ2​ is a corner on a surface, it's also a corner.

How about point cloud without intensity? Still covariance. Calculate the distance of [x',y',z'] to the plane.
M=[nx2nxnynxnznxnyny2nynznxnznynznz2]M=\left[\begin{matrix} {n_{x}}^{2} & n_{x}n_{y} & n_{x}n_{z}\\ n_{x}n_{y} & {n_{y}}^{2} & n_{y}n_{z}\\ n_{x}n_{z} & n_{y}n_{z} & {n_{z}}^{2} \end{matrix}\right]M=⎣⎡​nx​2nx​ny​nx​nz​​nx​ny​ny​2ny​nz​​nx​nz​ny​nz​nz​2​⎦⎤​
M is the covariance matrix of surface normal over the surface.

Native in 3D geometry -- ISS(Intrinsic Shape Signatures)

ISS is a shape descriptor for 3D object recognition.
Keypoints are those have large variations in their neighborhood.
How to detect keypoints? PCA(principle component analysis) to get the smallest eigenvalue of the covariance matrix, if it's large, find a keypoint!
Eigenvalues of Cov(pi)Cov(p_{i})Cov(pi​) are λi1{\lambda_{i}}^1λi​1，λi2{\lambda_{i}}^2λi​2，λi3{\lambda_{i}}^3λi​3, in the decreasing order.
A flat surface can be λi1=λi2>λi3{\lambda_{i}}^1={\lambda_{i}}^2>{\lambda_{i}}^3λi​1=λi​2>λi​3.
A line can be λi1>λi2=λi3{\lambda_{i}}^1>{\lambda_{i}}^2={\lambda_{i}}^3λi​1>λi​2=λi​3.
Take a NMS(non-maximum suppression) to exclude similar eigenvalue, thus remove noise's effect, because we have to ensure λi1>λi2>λi3{\lambda_{i}}^1>{\lambda_{i}}^2>{\lambda_{i}}^3λi​1>λi​2>λi​3.

Deep learning method

The traditional methods have a common disadvantage, that's sensitive to noise.
At the same time, very few deep learnig method for feature detection in point cloud, because the difinition of "feature" is unclear, it's sensitive to scale, density.

USIP

unsupervised stable interest point.

3DFeat-Net

Weakly supervised local 3D features for point cloud registration.

entry.title: LiDAR feature description
entry.content:
feature description: Extract a vector from the neighbour points of the interest point.

Classical method

Histogram based

Encode local geometric variations into a histogram.

PFH(Point Feature Histogram)

Input: point coordinates, surface normal vectors, query point
Output: Array of length B3B^{3}B3. There are 3 histograms, B is the bins of each histogram.
Ideas: capture the surface variations in a neighborhood, the perception field is [r].
PFH conside each pair within this patch, include query-neighbor, neighbor-neighbor. Each pair of points described by a triplet voxel grid, each axis is α,ϕ,θ\alpha, \phi, \thetaα,ϕ,θ, therefore the array size is B3B^{3}B3.

FPFH(Fast Point Feature Histogram)

When conside each pair within a patch, only include query-neighbor pair, do not have to build neighbor-neighbor pair, but will take the neighbor points as a query point for next step, and only one "next step", not endless. The 2 step search made the perception field to be [r, 2r].
Do not build a voxelgrid, but just concatenate into a vector, that's [α,ϕ,θ\alpha, \phi, \thetaα,ϕ,θ], therefore the array size is 3B3B3B.

Signature based

Both PFH and FPFH are orientation sensitive, how to solve this issue?
How to make descriptor robust to rotation?
-- Compute geometric measures based on Local Reference Frame(LRF).
The LRF is based on PCA, it's not relate to orientation, but only relate to the structure of points. Each principle vector has two directions: positive and negative.

SHOT

Division into 32 volumes in 3 aspects.
1, 8 azimuth division. [0~45°], [45~90°],..., [270~315°], [315~360°].
2, 2 elevation division. Northern hemisphere, Southern hemisphere.
3, 2 radial division. Sphere in radius r, Sphere in radius 2r.
Idea: Vote probabilisticly to reduce bias from boundary effect. Voting both for the located volume, and the neighbor volumn.

Deep learning methods

(Signature of Histogrames of OrienTations)
Advantages of deep learning method: Easy to include semantic information, smarter way to encode geometry, robust to noise.

PPFNet(Point Pair Feature NETwork)

Build Descriptor

How to encode a patch for PointNet
1, (x,y,z) at least.
For query point, find it's neighbors by kNN/RadiusNN, stack the query point and neighbors into Mx3 matrix.
2, surface normal
Surface normal vectors can improve classfication/segmentation.
3, pair-wise features
Pair-wise features like PFH
Therefore, the point pair features(PPF) can be described as
Fr=[x0...xkn0...nkppf(xr,x0,nr,n0)ppf(xr,x1,nr,n1)...ppf(xr,xk,nr,nk)]F_r=\left[\begin{matrix} x_0\\ ...\\ x_k\\ n_0\\ ...\\ n_k\\ ppf(x_r, x_0, n_r, n_0)\\ ppf(x_r, x_1, n_r, n_1)\\ ...\\ ppf(x_r, x_k, n_r, n_k) \end{matrix}\right]Fr​=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​x0​...xk​n0​...nk​ppf(xr​,x0​,nr​,n0​)ppf(xr​,x1​,nr​,n1​)...ppf(xr​,xk​,nr​,nk​)​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​

Local feature

Feed FrF_rFr​ into a shared PointNet.

Global feature

maxpool of all local features in the same frame.

Final feature

Concatenate local feature and global feature, then take a MLP.

Loss function

Consider 2 frames at a time, and N keypoints/patches at each frame.
In 2 frames, N to N association -> N tuples.
Corresponding matrix M: shape in NxN, it's a binary mask to describe the Euclidean space distance, 1 for positive, 0 for negative.
Distance matrix D: shape in NxN, describe the feature space distance
Similar samples stay togetherm, unsimilar samples stay away.
The N-tuple loss is the positive&negative matches which combines the M&D matrix.
Why N-tuple loss is addvanced? Because it combined the global feature, therefore make use of the global information.

entry.title: camera driver on Linux-V4L2(video for linux two)
entry.content:
Environment

Camera sensor(CMOS) is Aptina AR0143.
Renesas R-Car H3.
OS: Renesas Yocto Linux.

Task

In our driverless car system, there are 4 fisheye cameras, located at the front,back,left and right side of our car, we call them a surround-view camera.
In this camera driver programming task, I do not focus on how to power the sensor, how to register it on an I2C bus, my task is: How to capture raw frames in an application software component, that's to say, how to transfer the image data from kernel to user space.

Streaming

In this peoject, we adopt 2 ways in raw data streaming, one is memory mapping, and the other one is user pointer.
In memory mapping, ioctl request/release buffers in physic address, call the “mmap” mapping and “munmap” unmapping the physic address into user virtual address.
In user pointer method, the application software component allocate and release the memory, and give the pointer to V4L2 driver, the driver will save the image data in this pointer's memory.

Workflow

No matter which method to allocate the memory, the process is the same one.

1), open_device

2), init_device:

set image size, format and frame rate, and allocate memory in memory mapping or user pointer method I mentioned above.

3), Start_capturing:

VIDIOC_QBUF get data from buffer and show it on screen.

4), open_fb():

open the fbfd(frame buffer file descriptor), Map the device to memory.

5), mainloop():

it's a loop of read_frame, in read_frame function, read device’s file descriptor, transform image data from device -> memory -> application software component.
xioctl(fd[dev], VIDIOC_DQBUF, &buf) //VIDIOC_DQBUF: put image data into a buffer.
xioctl(fd[dev], VIDIOC_QBUF, &buf)//VIDIOC_QBUF：get image data from buffer.
xioctl(fd[dev], VIDIOC_STREAMON, &type)//VIDIOC_STREAMON: show the image on screen.

6), close_fb():

close fbfd(frame buffer file descriptor).

7), stop_capturing(dev):

stop the screen showing

8), uninit_device(dev):

release the memory

9), close_device(dev):

close device’s file descriptor

entry.title: pose description
entry.content:
Rotation matrix

The most commonly used method, the homogeneous form fully describe the motion/transform(R+T), while inhomogeneous form only describe the rotation(R), not translation(T) included.

Disadvantages

Taking 9 numbers to describe 3 DOF, there is information redundancy.

Axis-Angle

It also called Rotation vector, Euler vector.
In this case, both the rotation axis and the angle are represented by a vector θ=θn\bm{ \theta} = \theta\bm{n}θ=θn, n\bm{n}n is the rotation axis and θ\thetaθ is the rotation angle.

Disadvantages

It's singularity.

Axis-Angle VS Rotation matrix

Rotation matrix R=cos⁡θI+(1−cos⁡θ)nnT+sin⁡θn∧\cos{\theta}\bm{I} + (1-\cos{\theta})\bm{n}\bm{n}^{T} + \sin{\theta}\bm{n}^\landcosθI+(1−cosθ)nnT+sinθn∧.

Rotation matrix to Axis-Angle

θ=arccos⁡(tr(R)−12)\theta = \arccos(\dfrac{tr(R)-1}{2})θ=arccos(2tr(R)−1​)

Euler-Angle

Take a vector [yaw,pitch,roll] to express rotation based on Z-axis, Y-axis, X-axis sequentially. It's wildly used in robotic arms.

Rx(α)=[1000cos⁡(α)−sin⁡(α)0sin⁡(α)cos⁡(α)]R_{x}(\alpha)= \left[ \begin{matrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \cos(\alpha) & -\sin(\alpha) \\ 0 & \sin(\alpha) & \cos(\alpha) \end{matrix} \right] Rx​(α)=⎣⎡​100​0cos(α)sin(α)​0−sin(α)cos(α)​⎦⎤​

Rz(γ)=[cos⁡(γ)−sin⁡(γ)0sin⁡(γ)cos⁡(γ)0001]R_{z}(\gamma)= \left[ \begin{matrix} \cos(\gamma) & -\sin(\gamma) & 0 \\ \sin(\gamma) & \cos(\gamma) & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{matrix} \right] Rz​(γ)=⎣⎡​cos(γ)sin(γ)0​−sin(γ)cos(γ)0​001​⎦⎤​

Advantage

It's easy to understand, therefore usually used to display, not for calculation.

Disadvantages

It may comes into Gimbal lock issue, that's if the coordinate takes a 90° pitch, the X-axis and Z-axis can not be distinguished.

Quaternion

It combines a real value and imagenary vector, and it's generally represented in this form: q=q0+q1i+q2j+q3k\bm{q}=q_{0} + q_{1}i + q_{2}j + q_{3}kq=q0​+q1​i+q2​j+q3​k
i, j ,k are imagenary part, they are the fundamental quaternion units.

Advantage

It's nonsingular, and no redundancy;
It's easy to take Interpolation. The slerp(spherical linear interpolation) and squad, they are usually used in interpolation between keyframes.

entry.title: imageSentimentClassification - Kaggle Competition
entry.content:
Resources

My code
dataset

Task

Image classification and explain your model.

Data augement

In the training data set, faces in different sizes and positions, different tilting angles, and some facing left but some others are in the right direction. These unimportant features allow us to modify them to enrich our training data set. The Keras ImageDataGenerator is a function that can transform images randomly, within the user defined restrictions. In this project, the restrictions defined as

datagen = ImageDataGenerator(rotation_range=40, zoom_range=0.4, width_shift_range = 0.2, height_shift_range=0.2,
                                 shear_range=0.1, horizontal_flip=True,
                                 fill_mode='nearest', dtype='uint8')

Those generated images can reduce overfitting, and this kind of data augement method can reduce memory usage.

Image Contrast Enhancement

In our training data, some images are too dark or too bright, it's hard to see faces. To avoid the effects of light, histogram equalization was used to balance pixel distribution and adjust the picture contrast.

    # statistical gray scale distribution
    def calcHistogram(self,image):
        grayStatistic = [0] * 256  # how many pixels in each gray scale
        w = image.shape[0]
        h = image.shape[1]
        for i in range(w):
            for j in range(h):
                gray = image[i, j]
                grayStatistic[gray] += 1
        return grayStatistic

    # according to the gray scale distribution of a image, make equalization
    def histEqualization(self,grayStatistic, image):
        b = [0] * 256  # save gray scale ratio
        c = [0] * 256  # save accumulated counts
        w = image.shape[0]
        h = image.shape[1]
        mn = w * h * 1.0
        img = np.zeros([w, h], np.uint8)  # save img after equalization
        for i in range(len(grayStatistic)):
            b[i] = grayStatistic[i] / mn
        # accumulate
        for i in range(len(c)):
            if i == 1:
                c[i] = b[i]
            else:
                c[i] = c[i - 1] + b[i]
                grayStatistic[i] = int(255 * c[i])
        # equalization
        for i in range(w):
            for j in range(h):
                img[i, j] = grayStatistic[image[i, j]]
        return img

Model

The model is a combination of truncated Vgg16 and NiN. I take 3 blocks of Vgg16, connected with a NiN block. The NiN is Network-In-Network, it has two significant improvements in neural network, one is MLP-conv(multilayer perceptron), and the other one is GAP(global average pooling). In my project, the MLP-conv consists of a 3x3 conv layer and two 1x1 conv layers. To avoid gradient vanish and overfitting, batch normalization is added between 3x3 conv layer and “Relu” activation, and Dropout follows 1x1 conv layer. The GAP layer takes the average of each feature map, the resulting vector is fed directly into the softmax layer.

Visualize CNN filter by gradient ascent

Filter visualization displays the features extracted by a convolution kernel, it's used to explain the model.
Randomly choosing some filters in the target convolution layer, then get their gradient loss and do gradient ascent to add gradient loss on random noise, we can find what features those filters are extracting.

Adding gradient loss of each filter on the origin image, we can find out what those filters do on our images. The following image demonstrated that the last conv layer can extract eyes and facial contour features.

Saliency Map

In saliency map, we find the important areas on the face are highlighted by neural networks.

Confusion Matrix

In the training data set, the "disgust" data are rare, therefore, for other kinds of sentiment, it's not easy to be misjudged as disgust.

entry.title: Graph neural network - GCN, DGCNN
entry.content:
Graph neural networks are usually used in social network, citation network, molecules and 3D mesh, because in these fields, data are represented in the form of graphs. For example, the interactions between users and products in e-commence, the molecules in chemistry, are modeled as graphs(Wu et al. 2020). A graph consists of vertices and edges, the edge describes the relativity of the two vertices it connects. As graph can be irregular, it may have a variable size of unordered vertices, and vertices from a graph may have a different number of neighbors, this feature makes it suitable for LiDAR point clouds due to their irregular, unstructed and orderless.

In this article, I introduce two GCN models, the General GCN and the Dynamic Graph CNN(DGCNN), they are suitable for CNN-based high-level tasks on point clouds including classification and segmentation.

GCN

In GCN, the propagation steps include aggregation and update(Zhou et al. 2018). Take a designated vertex as an example, in the aggregation step, the information of itself and all of its neighbors are collected in a feature map(shaped in n⋅Cinn\cdot C_{in}n⋅Cin​), n is the number of neighbors, CinC_{in}Cin​ is the dimension of input feature vector for each point. In the update step, applying a learnable layer(a multi-layer perception(MLP)) to transform the aggregated features obtained in the aggregation step. The MLP consists of a linear(fully connected) layer( W∈RCin×CoutW \in \mathbb{R}^{C_{in} \times C_{out}}W∈RCin​×Cout​ ), followed by an activation layer(e.g, Relu). After the MLP, output the final feature map shaped in n⋅Coutn\cdot C_{out}n⋅Cout​.

In GCN, graph structure is represented by a matrix, like the kernel in CNN, the matrix carries the weights between any two vertices. However, this matrix can not be trained, it is uniquely determined by the graph. Take the graph below as a example, I will introduce various matrices to optimize the GCN model. For simplicity, the weights between each vertex are unified into 1.

Similarity matrix

In similarity matrix(also named adjacency matrix, connectivity matrix), each vertex itself is not considered, therefore the diagonal elements of similarity matrix A is 0.

In aggregation step, features from neighbors are gathered by weighted average or weighted sum, the matrix expression of the aggregation step is N=A⋅XN=A\cdot XN=A⋅X.
In update step, the output is a feature map H, H=σ(N⋅W)=σ(AXW)H=\sigma(N\cdot W)=\sigma(AXW)H=σ(N⋅W)=σ(AXW).

The similarity matrix method has 2 disadvantages：
1, The information of each vertex itself is lost.
2, The matrix A is not normalized, which may cause vertices with many neighbors dominating the model, while other vertices will be ignored.
The solution to the above 2 problems are normalized laplacian matrix method.
